participants.participant: Christine Ritz, Head of Investor Relations
Hans Dieter Pötsch, Member of the Board of Management, Finance and Controlling
Christian Klingler, Member of the Board of Management, Sales

plist.p: Good day and welcome to the Interim Report January to March 2010 of Volkswagen AG. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Christine Ritz, Head of Group Investor Relations, Volkswagen AG. Please go ahead, ma'am.

Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Volkswagen's conference call on the results for the period January to March 2010. I'm joined today by Hans Dieter Pötsch, Member of the Board of Management, Volkswagen AG responsible for Finance and Controlling, and for the first time for a Volkswagen earnings conference call by Christian Klingler, Member of the Board of Management, Volkswagen AG, responsible for Group Sales and Marketing.

Last week we released summary details on our financial performance, with our full interim report published this morning. As usual, you can also follow the webcast and download the charts from our website www.volkswagenag.com/ir. Questions can be sent by e-mail or called in.
Before we start, I would like to mention that after the presentation we will first respond to the questions of analysts and later under those of journalists.
I would now like to pass you over to Mr. Pötsch.
Thank you and a warm welcome also from my side to this call today.

The key to our performance in Q1 was clearly the rebound in global car demand from the very low levels at the start of 2009. With our attractive new models, we have been able to capture an above average share of this growth led by our excellent performance in China. The low Q1 2009 operating result was depressed by measures, in particular, the lowering of production to cut inventory levels offset in part through the one-off gain from the sale of our heavy truck assets in Brazil.

While the German market is weak following the ending of the scrapping support, our exposure to the emerging growth markets coupled with good performance in Western European markets outside Germany has driven the improvement in operating result to 848 million from €312 million last year.

Our focused discipline on working capital and investment continues supporting an excellent level of net liquidity in our automotive division of €14.2 billion. Two significant impacts here are worth mentioning in a little more detail. Firstly, we had an outflow of €1.7 billion for our stake of just under 20% in Suzuki. Joint teams of Volkswagen and Suzuki engineers are now working closely together. As we examine a range of potential project, progress so far is very positive for both parties.

And of course, you're all aware that we successfully raised a net €4.1 billion from the issuance of around 65 million preference shares. Due to the nature of the transaction, just around €3 billion of the total raised was received in the first quarter with the balance received in April. We are grateful for the trust placed in us by our new and existing shareholders and warmly welcome new shareholders to our company.
Mr. Klingler, over to you now.

Thank you very much, Mr. Pötsch. A very warm welcome also from my side, ladies and gentlemen. If you can open the charts, you see on this chart development of the world car market last year by quarter. And as well, the first quarter of this year in comparison to the previous one.

After a dramatic decline of 21% in the first quarter of 2009, the world market showed the first signs of relief, falling only 13% in the second quarter. The market bottomed out in the third quarter and recorded growth by 17 and 19% respectively in the past two quarters.

However, I have to add some note of cautions. As the car market started to decline from May 2008, the comparison with the previous year's figures shows signs of improvement in relative terms only, while in absolute terms the markets are stabilizing on a low level. To avoid the statistical distortion, a comparison to the last normal year of 2007 seems to be very appropriate.

So let's go to the next chart. In the second half of 2009 the market grew mainly as a result of the positive influence of the government support measures in many countries. The first quarter of 2010 almost reached the same level as in the normalized year of 2007, again, driven by additional registrations of vehicle contracted in late 2009 before the ending of the scrapping incentive programs in some of the major markets.

In the second quarter 2010 we expect, as you can see, a gradual normalization of the market trend as the positive effects of the incentive programs start fading out. However, our latest estimation suggests a decline in second half of the year 2010 due mainly to the negative impact of the advanced, let's say, pull-ahead sales in 2009 and the ending of the support measures in major European markets. This will make the second half of 2010 a very difficult period for the whole automotive industry.

As a whole, the car market in Europe is expected to contract further in 2010, while North and South America as well as Africa are set to maintain their recovery, which has already started in 2009. Despite continuous growth in Asia and robust recovery in North America this year, the world car market will fail to reach its pre-crisis volume again.

So if you go to the next chart. Since the second quarter of 2009 our deliveries to customers have shown a positive year-on-year development. In the first quarter of 2010 the Volkswagen Group again outperformed the overall car market, as you can see. This was supported by development in China, in North and South America as well as some Western European countries like Spain and Great Britain. Overall, as a result of our outperformance we continue to gain global market share.

If you would like to go to the next chart. Looking at our performance on a regional base, here you can see the success of the Volkswagen Group in direct comparison to the markets around the world. In every region we have outperformed the markets. Only in Central and Eastern Europe our deliveries to customers declined in comparison to last year by about 9%. But even here we are still better than the markets, which declined by nearly 23%.

This decline in the region was mainly caused by the Russian market, which contracted heavily by about 27% due to the credit crunch and the massive depreciation of the ruble. So since there there's a scrappage campaign now in Russia which has started last month, unfortunately mostly give an advantage to the Russian manufactures and not to the foreign manufacturers as Lada's taken 75% of the scrappage campaigns on its roll.

Now if you go to the next page, now turning to the deliveries in absolute numbers by market areas compared to last year. In the first quarter of 2010 our deliveries to customers of the total group exceeded last year's level by 24.4% despite the massive decline of the German car market. After the end of the scrapping campaign, our deliveries increased in Germany by 1.3% and in Western Europe as a whole by 16.4%.

Now if we go further, looking at the performance of the individual brands of the group. In the first quarter of 2010, all brands achieved an increase in terms of sales. Books on passenger cars recorded the highest growth in the group, delivering 27% more cars than last year, up to over 1.1 million units, driven by strong demand in China, which was up by plus 54%, and Western Europe up by 21%.

Audi's deliveries were up by an impressive 26% to more than 260,000 cars. Premium brands only marginally benefited from the stimulus programs in the European countries and in the United States. So as the world economy begins to recover, we anticipate growth for premium cars.
Škoda and SEAT recorded double digit growth, helping them to maintain their market shares in a recovery market environment.
Bentley benefited mainly from growing wealth in China, where deliveries almost doubled plus 90%, and from the recovery of the U.S. market.

Books for commercial vehicles and Scania participated in the recovery of light and heavy trucks market, especially in Brazil. Deliveries of Volkswagen commercial vehicles in total increased despite the exclusion of the Brazilian trucks and buses, which are now part of MAN since March 2009.
So, ladies and gentlemen, some highlight of our new models, which we will provide us a strong base for further sales performance in the coming months.
The Touareg Hybrid. The first Volkswagen SUV to be offered in hybrid version has been introduced on the markets this month.

The Audi A1 with its emotional design, driving pleasure, customization options and modern information communication technology will capture a new segment for Audi. The A1 will hit the road in August this year.

The new Sharan sets standards in its segments with lower consumption and low running costs. It combines the highest reliability with ease of handling and outstanding comfort as well as appealing aesthetics design. The new Sharan was recently shown at the Geneva Auto Show and will be introduced on the markets also in August.

The Amarok is the Volkswagen amongst pickups, smart solutions, German engineered. Its fuel efficiency is best in class, and with the drive concept, which means the two wheel drive and the four wheel drive, and assist systems, it is ready for all terrains tested by the car.
Thank you, Mr. Klinger. Mr. Pötsch, can you take us through the financials, please?

Yes, of course, I can. And let's get started with the analysis of sales revenue. Unit sales ex-China grew by just over 20%. Our sales revenue, which excludes our Chinese joint ventures, grew almost in line at 19.4% to €28.6 billion. The key driver being obviously the substantial volume increase that Mr. Klinger just explained. But this growth in revenue was not just growth at any cost – we achieved an improvement in price and mix as well as a positive impact from currencies.

Having sold our heavy truck interests in Brazil to MAN in the first quarter last year, the absence of the sales in our books for this year resulted in a negative of €0.3 billion. Scania reported an uptick in sales revenue of 0.1 billion as the heavy truck markets showed signs of improvement from the depths of recession. Our financial services business similarly enjoyed a small improvement of €0.1 billion.

Now turning to operating profit. The positive volume effect was the major influence in an improvement from €0.3 billion to 0.8 billion versus the first quarter 2009. Combined volume with price and mix effect came to a total positive of €0.9 billion. Currency contributed a further €0.1 billion. You have no doubt heard a lot of comments about raw material costs rebounding as the global economy start to recover. Our strategy of purchasing on a global basis with a long-term view on our supplier relationships has contributed alongside our own ongoing efforts to improve our product costs in engineering and production to a saving of €0.2 billion in the first three months. We have targeted a total savings of more than €1 billion for 2010, and I am confident that we will attain this.

Scania again had an outstanding performance and contributed an improvement of €0.2 billion. Fixed costs and depreciation increased versus the first quarter last year by €0.3 billion. One element here related to higher wages following our agreement with the unions. Another part relates to higher development costs and investment as we grow our business with new models and invest in more fuel efficient as well as electric and hybrid powertrain technologies. The ramp up of production facilities in new markets also had an impact. The other negative versus last year reflects the one-off gain booked in 2009 from the sale of our activities in Resende that I already referred to.

Let's turn to cash flow in the automotive division. Operating cash flow improved 6.5% to €3 billion. A good performance from first quarter 2009 has been maintained as we continue disciplined management of our inventory levels, which, in unit terms, are on a slightly higher level than as at year end 2009 while remaining below the level of March last year. Our CapEx ratio of 3.5% will rise as the year progresses and we expect for the full year to come in within our long-standing target of around 6% of automotive revenues.

Moving to cash flows from investing activities, a couple of influences needs to be stripped out to get to the underlying performance, including the sale of our Brazil interests in 2009 and our investment in Suzuki this year.

As I mentioned in my opening remarks, Volkswagen has purchased just under 20% of the equity of Suzuki for €1.7 billion. On a like-for-like basis, the underlying cash flow in investing activities fell from €1.6 billion to 1.3 billion, demonstrating our effective management. In total, the operating and investing cash flow for the automotive division came in at a positive €31 million.

Now let's move on to the liquidity in our automotive division. The outflow of 1.7 billion for our investment in Suzuki was more than compensated by the proceeds of 3 billion booked in the first quarter from our capital increase of 4.1 billion. The balance of €1.1 billion from the capital increase has already been received in April.

The excellent balance of €14.2 billion gives us the foundation to progress with the formation of an integrated group of Volkswagen with Porsche free from any short-term external impact on the global economy or capital markets.

Last week at our AGM our shareholders granted the Board of Management a global authorization to issue bearer bonds with warrants and/or bearer convertible bonds in the period up to April the 21st, 2015. I would like to emphasize that there are no concrete plans at present as to whether and, if so, when it will be utilized. Let me add that we have committed ourselves to a six months lock up as part of the capital increase.

Now let's take a look now at the financial performance of our nine brands. I am delighted to report that our improvement in performance is reflected in the results of all of our brands. From a loss at the start of 2009, the Volkswagen brand has recovered to report an operating result of plus €460 million, equal to a margin of 2.2%.

Audi has performed excellently in the first quarter, reported a result of 478 million. Škoda, booked a plus of 100 million as deliveries in major Western European markets outside of Germany grew significantly, up almost 50%. SEAT narrowed its losses by close to 25%. In the face of a very difficult home economic environment the SEAT team is making good progress. Bentley reduced its loss as the luxury car market too remains difficult.

Commercial vehicles improved once the impact of the sale of Resende is excluded. Scania, as I mentioned before, performed excellently. We see the first signs of recovery in the truck sector and Scania is perfectly positioned to benefit as confidence returns.

The Other result includes the elimination of inter-company sales and also the adjustments required under IFRS for purchase price accounting with regards to our consolidation of Scania. The PPA charge for Scania remains in 2010, but on a lower level than last year resulting in a consolidated net plus for Scania. Financial services reported a steady 167 million result. Combining the automotive and financial services divisions gives a total operating profit of €884 million.

The financial result improved to a negative 145 million and is made up of three main sources. First, earnings from the equity consolidation of participations. Second, interest income and expense on cash excluding the trading operations of financial services. And thirdly, earnings on options and the evaluations of other financial instruments, including long-term provisions such as pension funds.

Now, while the second and third sources remained broadly constant, the Chinese joint ventures were the main driver of the improvement in the overall financial results, reporting a proportional operating profit of €286 million, almost 3 times the level of the first quarter 2009, reflecting our very good sales performance.

Porsche is also included as equity following our investment in December 2009. While the operating business of Porsche was clearly positive in the quarter, the earnings included in our result are also subject to a PPA charge, which resulted in a small net loss in our books. Suzuki is also included here for the first time, and equally after purchase price accounting reported a small loss.

This leads me to our 2010 outlook, which you can read in detail in the interim report. Our presence in all the key regions around the world, the multi-brand strategy, our technological expertise and the most up to date, most environmentally friendly and broadest vehicle range that has resulted from that expertise are key advantages for our company.

2010, Volkswagen Group's nine brands will unveil a large number of new models thus systematically extending our position in the global markets. We therefore anticipate that our deliveries to customers will be higher than in 2009. The group's sales, revenue and operating profit for 2010 are expected to exceed the prior-year figures. Despite a shift in volumes between the markets, interest and exchange rate volatility will remain a drag on profit. We will continue to focus on disciplined cost and divestment management and the continuous optimization of our processes.

In summary, despite the positive performance in the first quarter, we remain cautious on the full-year market development as government support schemes run out and consumer demand will be driven by the underlying economic framework conditions.
While pessimism has switched to optimism, we will stick to our conservative stance while conditions remain uncertain.
Mr. Pötsch, thank you very much. We will now begin with the questions and answer part of today's conference call, starting first with the questions of analysts.
Thank you. We will take our first question from Horst Schneider of HSBC. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. Horst Schneider here from HSBC. Three or four questions if I may. The first one is regarding the visibility in your order book. Maybe you can specify it until which months you have got now somewhat better visibility. And in that context, I would be interested to know if Q2 volumes will be on the same level as in Q1 or maybe even higher?

And then I would be interested to know why your current liabilities in the balance sheet have increased to such a large extent this year end. So what is behind that increase? Is it again a higher provisions and hefty professions again for higher or for lower residual values and deleverage? So maybe you could specify how much you have provisioned for that items.

And then a last question I have is on price and mix. I see that you had in the first quarter – at least on the revenue line here, a positive impact from price and mix. Would you expect that also on a full-year basis? Thank you.

Yeah, thank you very much. Horst Schneider had three questions for us. First he would like to know if we can share some details on our order book, if you have a better visibility now and if Q2 volumes will be on the same level as Q1. Then there is a question about the liabilities and higher provisions, if we can give here some more details if this is related to lower residual values or any dealer risks. And the last question relates on our development in the revenue, if the – because we have seen that price and mix is positive and if this is also a valid estimation for the full year. Thank you.

So maybe I start with the answer on the order book. The order book, let's say, concerning the order intake in the first quarter was better than anticipated. So we see a better demand in Germany as well as we see in Western Europe as well as in the other regions. So our order book is in a pretty reasonable shape.

How will be the tendency in quarter 2? The first signs seems to be satisfying and seems to be pretty okay. As well as we have shown before, the seasonality in this year will be much stronger in the first half of the year than in the second half of the year due to the market, as the second half of the year, the market will go down.

Concerning pricing and mix, we have of course taken advantage of the new models, and as consequence, the possibility to have a pretty reasonable price and mix possibility in the markets. We estimate that it can be for the next quarter a tendency which seems to be similar to this. What will happen afterwards, it's depending on the conditions of the markets.

Okay. Then I can continue with the question concerning the liabilities. Now, first of all a pretty comment as the business is growing again, the pipeline is filling up. It's clear that there are also the liabilities growing in this specific phase over-proportionally. Now, on the provision side, I think I can remind you to the statement we made with regards to the fourth quarter and the third quarter 2009 where we specifically were covering the potential risks on the residual side and also as far as dealer risks were concerned.

So in the development of the first quarter 2010, there are no specific issues in terms of provisions built for residuals and dealer risks. The main driver behind the build up of provisions are on the one hand the translatory effect coming out of currencies and while you can also remind yourself to the currency situation specifically in what we called the smaller currencies, for example, in the east of Europe. This situation got reversed in the meantime, which is producing a positive effect on the P&L side of the business. But in terms, for example, of pension obligations, of course, means a revaluation, which is contributing to the opposite.

Another element of course here is also that as the business is being built up back again, some areas are affected, for example, warranties, for example, provisions for all the general marketing and sales expenses. And these are the main reasons why the provisions had to be built up in the first quarter of 2010.

Sorry, add-on question to that. If I got it right then, you said that part of the provisions will be returned again in the second quarter. Is that right related to currencies or have I got that wrong?

No, I said of course when you are closing the books of course you have to refer to the currency relationship. And as we saw some firming up of currencies other than Euro, there is a decent effect included, which refers to that point. Now, we needed to know on how these currencies are going to develop further to know exactly which way we are going here.

Again, just to avoid that there is any sort of misunderstanding, this does not mean to any extent any additional burden, commitment or whatever it is, it is just the translation from a non-euro currency into euros, which, of course, can fluctuate.
Okay. Thank you.
Let's have the next question, please.
We move onto our next question, which comes from Adam Hull of WestLB. Please go ahead.

Hi. Good afternoon. I was going to ask on provisions but maybe I'll hold back a little bit. Could you just give us a little bit more explanation on the PPA charge both within the other eliminations of 366 million and also just a little bit more in the financial line? What is the total PPA in both lines, so we can get a sort of an estimate for trying to strip out effectively non-cash?

And then secondly – well, maybe going just back to the provisions for a moment, I mean, you've charged the P&L with these provisions and then you reversed them in the automotive cash flow at 1.3 billion. Maybe you could just help us a little bit as to how that exactly has worked, because it does seem a very large reversal in the cash flow. Thanks.

Okay. Adam has two questions for us. So the first question is related to the PPA, if we can give them more details where what we have charged, and in the other eliminations or in the financial results, if we can give here some more details. And then again a question with regard to provisions, if we can explain a little bit better what happened in the P&L and in the automotive cash flow? Thank you.

So on the first question, as far as PPA is concerned, we have a total effect on the bottom line in the first quarter of 2010 in the neighborhood of €160 million. And that's clearly then including the PPA effect on Scania, on Porsche, on MAN and Suzuki. Now, looking at the figure for the full year, from today's point of view it looks as if we are moving in an area of around 600 million PPA effect, so a quite substantial number. And it goes without saying that this is an effect which doesn't have any cash effect aside it.

To the second question on the provisioning, I think it's very important also to understand, as I pointed out already, that, for example, the effect with regards to currencies, which I mentioned, is just accounting or bookkeeping, it doesn't have any cash effect.

So this means if we look at the P&L, of course it has to be fully considered in the P&L, while in the cash flow statements, it has to be reversed because the cash flow statement is built on the basis of the P&L. And in order to identify on whether a specific item is cash relevant or not, you then have to look into the cash flow statement. So there it's clearly been reversed for the reason that, let's say, the large magnitude of provisioning did at least so far not have any effect on the cash side.
If I could just be clear on the number, your 160 and 600 million on the PPA, I'm presuming that's a pre-tax number.
That's an after-tax number.

An after-tax number. Okay. And then just maybe just an add-on, just on the MAN and Porsche, are you estimating that, I guess, the profits to the end of March then for both or is that a lag? Just remind us of that. And thank you.

My comment on the Porsche side was just for the three months of 2010 where I said that clearly Porsche is in the black, a 3 digit number in the black, but we have to consider the PPA effect. So net of all that means a slightly red number for Porsche including PPA.
Thank you.
Thank you. We move onto our next question which comes from Thierry Huon of Exane. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. It's Thierry Huon speaking from Exane. Two quick questions. One regarding CapEx. You are well below at the end of Q1 from your 6% target. You mentioned during your presentation that you should get close to the 6%. So how close should we expect you to be from this 6%? It's going to be 5 or more like 6?
And second question, could you give us the inventories number you are sharing with us usually for the group at the independent dealer level and for the group level? Thank you.

Okay. Thank you, Thierry. You have two questions for us. The first question refers to CapEx. In the first quarter we had quite a ratio well below 6% and you would like to know what is our guidance for the full year. And the second question relates to inventories at group level, if we can give you some more information. Thank you.

I think you probably missed a certain area here in my first comment, because I said very clearly we believe for the full year we will be within the band which we feel is adequate for the company, which is around 6% CapEx to sales ratio.

Now on the inventory side, of course, my colleague sitting aside me should know part of the answer at least because it's very clear that it's heavily related to the point how the economy is going to develop further because you might also recall that in the past months we many fold times mentioned that we think on a normal basis our inventory levels are too low, but we feel it's adequate to the situation. Now, if the situation would improve further on, of course, we would have to build up some inventory to be closer to what our marketing and sales people are judging as being something as an ideal stock level. But maybe – but I'm sure, Mr. Klingler can add a few more comments on this.

Concerning inventory in general, we could say that we are still on a very strict control. We do have inventory levels which are very much controlled in all perspectives. So we do have the same inventory in March 2010 what we had in 2009 in December. We feel that in the consequence, we are very prudent on one hand but on the other hand we don't take the risk to lose any sales. We will keep on this policy because we believe that there are in some regions still some possible risks, as well as you have seen as in the beginning of the presentation, in the second half of the year there will be concerning our prognosis a market which will go down a little bit compared to the first half of the year.
Okay.
Let's have the next question, please.
We move on to our next question, which comes from Jürgen Piper of Metzler. Please go ahead.

Yes, hi. Good afternoon. I had two questions, now I have just one left. It's on SEAT. I mean, we see in the first quarter sales revenues going up by 39%, still the EBIT is almost as negative as in the first quarter of 2009. So a question – or if you want two questions, can you give us the level of revenues where today's – level at today's cost level you would be a breakeven? Or alternatively, do you have today a perspective when this breakeven could come?
Okay, thank you. Jürgen Piper has one question about SEAT, if we can give some information about the breakeven. When can the breakeven be achieved at SEAT and at which level of revenues? Thank you.

First of all, very quick comment on the situation 2010, I think SEAT started out quite positively into the year. Now, as you're well aware, SEAT is very much depending on the performance of the Southern European market, and that market is currently where there is some government support for these markets. It's difficult to say how long this support is going to continue on, so we want to just create some caution here on the further development.

Then more concrete to your question on the framework for the breakeven point. Now, clearly speaking, in terms of revenues it has to be more than today, but the answer to the question how can we get to the breakeven point is not only to be done on the revenue side of course. And you might be well aware that we took a fundamental decision to build one of the new Audi products in two years from now in a SEAT location in Martorell, and in doing so, of course, we do absorb a substantial amount of fixed costs which is creating this relief for SEAT. In parallel, of course we are heavily working on the fixed cost side there in general terms.

So the question is to be answered in a way that, yes, we need a more prosperous development in terms of revenues, but a very important contribution is to come from the cost side also by measures – which structural measures in taking fixed costs away from SEAT. We believe in roughly a two years timeframe that's a challenge which is to be mastered.
Thank you.
Next question, please.
We'll move on to our next question, which comes Jose Asumendi of RBS. Please go ahead.
Hi. Jose Asumendi, RBS. Three questions, please. Just to come back on the order book, could you please quantify how many months of sales have you got currently in your book?

The second one would be on the premium segment. Could you please quantify on average by how much have you managed to increase prices for Audi? And if you could please comment a little bit about your competitors BMW and Daimler, how are they progressing to restore the pricing in the market?

And the third one is, I mean, when I'm talking to the other OEMs everyone is talking about winning market share in especially in Europe. I was just wondering, what are your thoughts on market share for the second half? Thanks.

Okay, Jose. Thank you. You have three questions for us. The first question is again about our order book, if we can give some more details for the next month and if you can quantify that? And the next question relates to the premium segment, if we can increase prices for Audi, how is the situation there? And the last question refers to our market share, what do we expect for the second half, especially in Europe? Thank you.

Well, thank you very much for the questions; maybe I start with the last one. Concerning market share, we expect in general on a worldwide level a further increase of our market share. This will be as well the case in Western Europe. You only have to be aware that there is a base effect due to the differences of development of the countries, and this has to be integrated into this discussion as well.

Concerning the order book, as I said before, our order book – or our orders in the first quarter has been better than forecasted, so we're in a reasonably high level and as a consequence we're pretty confident for the next quarter to come.

Concerning the prices for Audi, or what are the competitors are doing, as you know, normally we are not commentaring the actions of our competitors. In general, I would say that the new models, like the Q5, like the A5 Sportback, like the A8, they have received a very good perception of our customers. And all of them have been presented to the market with a huge success. So in general we do have a very good possibility to come to the market with interesting price propositions for Audi.

Could I just add one more question, please? I was just wondering in relation to the scrapping plans in Europe and are being – if you listen what they are discussing, for example in Spain, there is a chance that they could implement a second round of scrapping incentives or some kind of help for the market, especially in Q3 and Q4. Do you also see that chance and do you see also any other chance at any other European country?

So coming back to Spain, as you know this campaign will end in the next few weeks or days depending when the volume is out of it. We don't know what the Spanish government will decide. So in our numbers, Spain is integrated without an additional campaign concerning scrappage. In general, we do not expect that further countries will come up with additional scrappage campaigns.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
Thank you. Let's have the next question.
We move on to our next question now, which comes from Michael Punzet of HSBC (sic) [DZ Bank] . Please go ahead.

Okay. Michael Punzet from DZ Bank. I have two questions. The first one is related to the charts on page 12 and 13 of your presentation. You posted a positive currency effect of 400 million in your revenues line, but only 100 million in your EBIT line. Maybe you can explain what's the reason for that, if that is related to unfavorable hedges and if the trend continues during the rest of the year?
And then on your VW brand, you posted a margin of 2.2% in Q1. Is that a level we could also expect for Q2 and maybe also for the full year? Thanks.

Okay. Michael Punzet has two questions for us. The first one relates to the currency impact on sales revenue and on operating profit, where does the difference come from, if we can explain that a little bit more? And the second question refers to the passenger car business. We have showed a margin of 2.2% in the first quarter, what do we expect for the second quarter and for the full year? Thank you.

To the first question, the answer is a bit simple, if you allow me to say. If you imagine a certain country where on the basis of a strong currency the revenues are positively supported, unfortunately you have a similar but negative development on the cost side on the same basis. So the result is of course – or must be much lower than what is stated on the revenue line.

On the margin side of the business, we think that the passenger car business can at least continue on with the margin shown in the first quarter. For the second quarter, for the second half of the year, we again have to remind you that there are some uncertainties on how the markets are going to perform further on volume-wise. And there we are again back to the big question on whether some of the incentives will be prolonged or whether they would be stopped and, of course, the general link to the economical framework conditions.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. We move on to our next question, which comes from Charles Winston of Redburn Partners. Please go ahead, sir.

Thank you, and hi, good afternoon. It was just two questions actually. The -- actually back to two topics we've been to already.
